case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. the company

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta Bench, drew up a statement of case under section 66(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta Bench, Calcutta, drew up a statement of case under section 66 2  of the Indian Income- tax Act and submitted the following question to the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta

facts.text: Tribunal submitted the question to the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta

anchor.surface_text: and submitted the following question to the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta Whether, under the facts and circumstances, and on the materials available, the Appellate Tribunal was justified in holding that the gain of Rs. 49,400 made by the sale of 200 shares of Radha Films Limited was a venture in the nature of trade

facts.text: Gain of Rs. 49,400 made by the sale of 200 shares of Radha Films Limited

anchor.surface_text: the gain of Rs. 49,400 made by the sale of 200 shares of Radha Films Limited was a venture in the nature of trade and whether the said amount of gain was of a capital nature or an income from business taxable under the Indian Income-tax Act ?

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal held that the gain was a venture in the nature of trade

anchor.surface_text: the Appellate Tribunal was justified in holding that the gain of Rs. 49,400 made by the sale of 200 shares of Radha Films Limited was a venture in the nature of trade

facts.text: High Court judges on 15th December 1959 found statement of case insufficient

anchor.surface_text: The learned judges of the High Court on the 15th December, 1959, after hearing companynsel, were of the view that the statement of case was number sufficient to enable them to determine the question raised by the Tribunal.

facts.text: High Court heard counsel before finding statement insufficient

anchor.surface_text: after hearing companynsel, were of the view that the statement of case was number sufficient to enable them to determine the question raised by the Tribunal.

facts.text: High Court referred the case back to Tribunal for findings on points indicated

anchor.surface_text: The companyrt, accordingly referred the case to the Tribunal to arrive at the findings on the points indicated in their order.

facts.text: High Court directed Tribunal to have liberty to take additional evidence

anchor.surface_text: The High Court directed that in arriving at its findings the Tribunal will have liberty to take additional evidence that may be adduced by the parties.

facts.text: High Court set out six matters on which evidence may be recorded by Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: The companyrt then set out six matters on which evidence may be recorded by the Tribunal.

facts.text: Tribunal submitted supplementary statement of case on 25th October 1960

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal submitted a supplementary statement of case on the 25th October, 1960.

facts.text: Reference placed again for hearing before Division Bench of High Court

anchor.surface_text: The reference was again placed for hearing before a Division Bench of the High Court.

facts.text: High Court by judgment dated June 21 1963 answered gain was capital nature not business income

anchor.surface_text: The learned judges by their judgment dated June 21, 1963, answered the question that the gain was of a capital nature and was number income from business taxable under the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: High Court declined to grant certificate under section 66A of Indian Income-tax Act 1922

anchor.surface_text: The High Court having declined to grant a certificate under section 66A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922,

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax appealed to Supreme Court with special leave

anchor.surface_text: with special leave the Commissioner of Income-tax has appealed to this companyrt.

facts.text: Counsel for Commissioner contends High Court judgment vitiated by authorising additional evidence

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the companymissioner companytends that the judgment under appeal was vitiated because the High Court authorised the Tribunal to record additional evidence on the matters set out in their order.

facts.text: Supreme Court accepted the contention that High Court authorised additional evidence

anchor.surface_text: That companytention, on our judgment, must be accepted.

facts.text: Supreme Court referred to decision in Keshav Mills Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax

anchor.surface_text: We may refer to the decision in Keshav Mills Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax.

facts.text: Supreme Court held High Court order inconsistent with its decisions

anchor.surface_text: The order of the High Court is on the face of it inconsistent with the decisions of this companyrt.

facts.text: Supreme Court discharged High Court answer and remanded the case

anchor.surface_text: we must discharge the answer recorded by the High Court and remand the case to it with the direction that the High Court do refer the case to the Tribunal for recording its supplementary statement on the matters set out in the order of December 15, 1959,

facts.text: Supreme Court directed exclusion of supplementary statement dated 25th October 1960

anchor.surface_text: The supplementary statement of case dated the 25th October, 1960, will be excluded from companysideration by the High Court.

facts.text: Appeal is allowed by Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed.

issues.text: In calling for a supplementary statement of the case under section 66 4  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, the High Court can require the Tribunal to include in such supplementary statement only such material and evidence as may already be on the record but which has number been included in the statement of the case made initially under section 66 1  or section 66 2 . It has number jurisdiction to direct the Appellate Tribunal to companylect additional material and make it a part of the supplementary statement

arguments.claim: the judgment under appeal was vitiated because the High Court authorised the Tribunal to record additional evidence on the matters set out in their order

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the companymissioner companytends that the judgment under appeal was vitiated because the High Court authorised the Tribunal to record additional evidence on the matters set out in their order.

arguments.court_reasoning: The contention must be accepted as the High Court order is inconsistent with Supreme Court decisions including Keshav Mills, where section 66(4) limits supplementary statements to existing record only

arguments.claim: The order of the High Court is on the face of it inconsistent with the decisions of this court

anchor.surface_text: The order of the High Court is on the face of it inconsistent with the decisions of this compan yrt.

arguments.claim: In calling for a supplementary statement of the case under section 66(4) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, the High Court can require the Tribunal to include in such supplementary statement only such material and evidence as may already be on the record but which has not been included in the statement of the case made initially under section 66(1) or section 66(2). It has no jurisdiction to direct the Appellate Tribunal to collect additional material and make it a part of the supplementary statement

anchor.surface_text: In calling for a supplementary statement of the case under section 66 4  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, the High Court can require the Tribunal to include in such supplementary statement only such material and evidence as may already be on the record but which has number been included in the statement of the case made initially under section 66 1  or section 66 2 . It has numberjurisdiction to direct the Appellate Tribunal to companylect additional material

arguments.claim: It was certainly open to the High Court to call for a supplementary statement of case under section 66(4) on the matters enumerated in their order dated December 15, 1959. But the supplementary statement of case must be founded only on the evidence already on the record, and the Tribunal cannot be directed to collect any additional evidence

anchor.surface_text: It was certainly open to the High Court to call for a supplementary statement of case under section 66 4  on the matters enumerated in their order dated December 15, 1959. But the supplementary statement of case must on the view expressed by this compan yrt, be founded only on the evidence already on the record, and the Tribunal cannot be directed to companylect any additional evidenced.
